import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os

source.1474d0dd:
contribution = df.groupby(['Model_Group'])['Selling_Price'].sum().sort_values(ascending = False)
contribution.plot(kind = 'pie', title = 'Samsung Mobile Phone Sales', figsize = [7, 7], 
  autopct = lambda p:'{:.1f}%'.format(p))
source.b7b59223:
model_list = df.groupby(['Model'])['Selling_Price'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False)
ax = model_list.plot (kind='bar', x='Model', y='Selling_Price', title="Selling Price by Model", rot=0, figsize=(20, 3))

for p in ax.patches: 
    left, bottom, width, height = p.get_bbox().bounds 
    ax.annotate("%.1fK"%(height/1e3), (left+width/2, height*1.01), ha='center')
    plt.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0.5))

plt.show()

source.a422f80a: Consumer review seems great as 57% said 'Good' while 14% said 'Usual'. Overally it is ok.
source.ba8b3c74: Explained above, there are few columns including Brand, Model, Payment method and Selling price.
source.f86ed7b7: It was nice to see the dataset, Samsung in particular. If we had more larget volume set of data, then the analysis could be more productive. Hope it helps and please give me 'Vote'. Thanks!
source.76847b83:
This actually needs to analyze by its model considering the phone is selling at various prices by its specification, sales location and brand etc.

As expected, 'Galaxy Note 20 Ultra' is selling at the highest price with 132K(Unit: BDT? not sure. Anyway) among the product, followed by 'Galaxy S 20 Ultra'.
source.a3c3ef05: We have around 48% of A series in the dataset followed by M series with 19% and 14% with Flagship. But what if we analyze by its sales volume?
source.c093d1a5: If we look at selling price by Ram size, Flagship shows higher selling prices as expected. A series seems to provide more various options as they are selling from 2GB to 8GB Ram as well.
source.a232c5ac:
Hi. Thanks for providing the interesting dataset. 

I found that there is a task regarding selling price. I barelly noticed that the dataset doesn't include the full dataset. I guess it is mainly because of the commercial usage issue provided by the data provider. 

Although there are small samples focusing on Samsung mobile phone, here below I tried to explain the market situation. One thing I concerned is that this is targeting Bangladesh market. Thus I may not fully understand the market specific issue. I hope your kinder understaing in regards with this. Thanks in advance.
source.74e6cb1b: Now 'Mobile_Phone' doesn't seem to be necessary. So I drop this column.
source.4c021eca: Also we can find data set by Ram size
source.a1155e60: Yes it is true. Considering the selling price of Flagship, Flagship market consists of around 46% if we look at by sales amount, folllowed by A series with 33%.
source.17b76d07: There are several model names in the column. I believe it is great to anlayze by its type. Considering the Galaxy Note and Galaxy S series are selling at higer price than A or M series. We can divdie them by product tier.
source.9c2e5e7a: However, the selling price on cash shows high variances as below.
source.b36e4c6f: In dataset, mostly comes from Galaxy.
source.755bfa15: Regarding payment methods, I do not understand bkash or rocket except for cash. It needs market understanding again.
source.09886d97: Also Rom size shows the same result. Flagship models are selling higher among the products.
source.32e09ddc: 'Mobile_Phone' includes 2 information like Brand and sub Brand. So I would like to separate this column by sub brand.
